# Tool Setup

This chapter provides a step-by-step recipe for installing and configuring all tools required for building course materials with Quarto, managing content with GitHub, and integrating outputs into Blackboard Ultra.

While GitHub is strongly recommended for version control and long-term course management, users who prefer to work entirely on local machines or cloud-synced drives (Google Drive, OneDrive, Dropbox, iCloud Drive) may skip the repository creation steps and proceed directly to **Chapter 3**.

However, the GitHub-based workflow—especially when paired with Antigravity or VS Code—is highly preferred for reproducibility, collaboration, and maintaining a clean version history of your teaching materials.

This recipe assumes no prior experience. Each step includes instructions, verification checks, and placeholders for screenshots.

## Install Git

Git is the version control system used throughout the recommended workflow. You can choose the platform from the installation on the [Git](https://git-scm.com/install) website.

![Installing Git - Linux Screenshot Placeholder](images/ch01/toolsetup-git.png){width=80% fig-align="center" #fig-git}

1. Install Git using your operating system:
   1. macOS:

     ```bash
     brew install git
     ```
   2. Windows: [Download](https://git-scm.com/download/win)
   3. Linux:

     ```bash
     sudo apt update && sudo apt install git -y
     ```
2. Verify installation:

   ```bash
   git --version
   ```

## Install GitHub CLI

GitHub CLI (`gh`) enables authentication and repository operations directly from the terminal. Download and install from: [GitHub CLI](https://cli.github.com/)

## Create Your GitHub Pages Repository

*(Optional for users who plan to work only on local/cloud drives)*

This step creates your personal website: `https://yourusername.github.io`

If you prefer to work without GitHub, skip to **Chapter 3**.
However, the GitHub-based workflow is strongly recommended.

1. Go to [https://github.com/new](https://github.com/new), or click on the + icon in the top-right corner of your GitHub dashboard shown in @fig-ghrepo.
2. Set repository name:
   1. `yourusername.github.io` creates your personal website repository
   2. For a course repository, use `coursenumber-coursename` (e.g. `AD688-big-data-and-cloud-computing`)

   ```
   yourusername.github.io
   ```
3. Select **Private**, since we want this to be available for instructors only.
4. Add README and `.gitignore`, you can choose the template to be `python` or `r` to avoid syncing the virtual environments to the git repo.
5. Create repository

![Create GitHub Repo](images/ch01/toolsetup-ghrepo.png){width=80% fig-align="center" #fig-ghrepo}

![Create GitHub Repo](images/ch01/toolsetup-ghrepo-options.png){width=80% fig-align="center" #fig-ghrepo2}

### Configure Git Identity and SSH Keys

*(Required only if using GitHub workflow)*

### Configure identity

```bash
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
```

### Generate an SSH key

```bash
ssh-keygen -t ed25519
```

## Add the public key to GitHub

```bash
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
```

Add it to [https://github.com/settings/keys](https://github.com/settings/keys)

## Test authentication

```bash
ssh -T git@github.com
```

![SSH Key Added](images/toolsetup-sshkey.png){width=80% fig-align="center" #fig-sshkey}

# Clone Your GitHub Pages Repository

*(Skip this step if not using GitHub)*

## Instructions

Clone repository:

```bash
git clone git@github.com:yourusername/yourusername.github.io.git
cd yourusername.github.io
```

Create a sample file:

```bash
echo "Welcome to my GitHub Pages site." >> index.md
```

Stage and commit:

```bash
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
```

Push:

```bash
git push origin main
```

Pull:

```bash
git pull
```

![Local Repo Clone](images/toolsetup-clone.png){width=80% fig-align="center" #fig-clone}

# Create Python and R Environments (Optional)

## Python virtual environment

```bash
python3 -m venv .venv
```

Activate:

macOS/Linux:

```bash
source .venv/bin/activate
```

Windows:

```powershell
.venv\Scripts\activate
```

Install packages:

```bash
pip install numpy pandas jupyter matplotlib quarto
```

## R environment using renv

```r
#| eval: false
#| echo: true
install.packages("renv")
renv::init()
install.packages(c("tidyverse", "knitr", "rmarkdown"))
renv::snapshot()
```

![Environment Setup](images/ch01/toolsetup-env.png){width=80% fig-align="center" #fig-env}
